results.title: Street XRays
results.brief_description:
Drawing on the NSW Police Department’s photographic archive, Street X-Rays interprets approximately sixty crime scenes from the 1950s, to evoke the power of the continuing life of the past in our ordinary, everyday places.

The police images are placed beside contemporary footage recorded in the same location, from the same camera position. Each screen holds two moments in time, two disparate attempts to interrogate a location. Texts from police records and the artist’s enigmatic narrative prompts punctuate this essentially visual dialogue. The effects of time linger in each scene and across the entire imaginative space of this half-historical/half-mythical city that is evoked in the installation space.

I’ve tried to conjure a place that’s haunted by persistent little pulses of history. I hope viewers feel as if they’ve wandered into a vaguely familiar ‘otherworld’ that’s being buffeted by a kind of ‘spirit weather’ - Ross Gibson.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: Dolores from 10 to 10
results.brief_description:
Dolores from 10 to 10 is a multi-channel installation, adapted from Fusco and Ricardo Dominguez’s 12-hour performance at Kiasma in Helsinki, which was streamed live to the internet in 2001. The work refers to the true story of a maquiladora (assembly line) worker, falsely accused of unionizing workers at her plant. Locked in an office for 12 hours without food, water, or telephone access, she was coerced into signing a letter of resignation. Her lawsuit against her employers was eventually denied on the grounds that she had no ‘proof’.

Dolores from 10 to 10 is Fusco’s interpretation of this real-life internment and a re-construction of what might have been seen if there had been surveillance cameras in the office. Framed by the female labour situation in Mexico, Fusco highlights the inequalities of the relationship between women and technology across the world.

results.title: BIT Plane
results.brief_description:
The Bitplane video captures an aero-portrait of a richly mythologised territory - the Silicon Valley in California, home to the largest concentration of wealth in California since the Gold Rush. The Bitplane’s mission takes it deep into the heart of the Valley, to view the source and progress of the Information Age. Due to its tiny dimensions, the Bitplane is able to enter territory inaccessible to other aircraft.

One of the issues the Bitplane engages with on this reconnaissance flight is the threat of the camera to information space. Cameras are not permitted into the corporate research parks in teh Valley, according to the logic that visitors could steal intellectual property by taking photographs. This reveals an assumption that information is something you can photograph, a thing - not the product of a community or expertise or a social network of shared discourse but something you could steal with a camera.

From the Artist Statement provided for PROOF exhibition, Dec 2004.

results.title: Olympic Games, Melbourne, Australia, 1956
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympics warranted the Straford Brothers using their cherished stock of coloured film to capture this unique event. Original footage of the Athletics field (notably pole vaulting), swimming and diving events in the pool have been compiled by Frank years later with additional video content and a voiceover. Despite shooting some of this additional footage on his living room floor (inadvertantly including a glimpse of shagpile carpet) and such ‘special effects’ as a whiteboard marker illustrating points on a map, the documentary has a lot of interesting detail about the event; about their personal experience of it and the novelty of seeing OB Television crews in action.

results.title: World to conquer
results.brief_description: This sci-fi ‘Straford Brothers Specialite’ is a scripted drama featuring local student actors. A classic sci-fi set up, it has some nifty DIY special effects including painstakingly made miniature sets (watch out for the alien control room!), animated spaceship and a alien periscope very reminiscent of early ‘Doctor Who’ episodes.

results.title: Let's go Roman
results.brief_description: This is the longest of the Little Claude animations and sees our hapless hero wreaking slapstick havoc with a catapault in Imperial Rome.

results.title: Roamin holiday
results.brief_description: Shot on a random bag of film stock and featuring footage of Inverloch, Marysville and Albury, this holiday footage is one of Frank Straford’s favourite ‘Highway rambles’. The title is a sly reference to the Hollywood film popular at the time.

results.title: Thirty years destroyed
results.brief_description: In this scripted drama, a mad scientist realises his life’s work - with deathly consequences. Borrows from classic horror movies of the period to irresistable effect.
